rev.diff:
Line 191: Line 191:
On May 5, 2011, Trump announced he would not be the celebrity pace-car driver for the 2011 [[Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] as was previously announced a month earlier by the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] (on April 5, 2011.)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/indycar/2011-05-05-trump-indy500_N.htm|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500; won't drive pace car|author=Curt Cavin|coauthor=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|published by = USA Today|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/default/news/show/42166-global-icon-trump-to-drive-100th-anniversary-indianapolis-500-pace-car/|title=Global Icon Trump To Drive 100th Anniversary Indianapolis 500 Pace Car|author=Paul Kelly|work=Indianapolis Motor Speedway|date=April 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> Trump stated he made the decision because of business constraints, but there had been a fan campaign for the Speedway to instead name a racing celebrity to the position<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20110504/ENTERTAINMENT/105040329/Campaign-grows-set-early-bump-day-Trump?odyssey=tab|topnews|text|Sports|title=Campaign grows to set early bump day for Trump|author=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|date= May 4, 2011|accessdate= May 11, 2011}}</ref> and a Speedway press release stated that Trump cancelled because of his intention to run for President.<ref>{{cite news|author=Weir, Tom|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500 pace car role|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/05/donald-trump-bows-out-of-indy-500-pace-car-role/1|date=May 5, 2011|work=USA Today|publisher=Gannett|accessdate=May 7, 2011}}</ref>
On May 5, 2011, Trump announced he would not be the celebrity pace-car driver for the 2011 [[Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] as was previously announced a month earlier by the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]] (on April 5, 2011.)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/motor/indycar/2011-05-05-trump-indy500_N.htm|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500; won't drive pace car|author=Curt Cavin|coauthor=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|published by = USA Today|date=May 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianapolismotorspeedway.com/default/news/show/42166-global-icon-trump-to-drive-100th-anniversary-indianapolis-500-pace-car/|title=Global Icon Trump To Drive 100th Anniversary Indianapolis 500 Pace Car|author=Paul Kelly|work=Indianapolis Motor Speedway|date=April 5, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}}</ref> Trump stated he made the decision because of business constraints, but there had been a fan campaign for the Speedway to instead name a racing celebrity to the position<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20110504/ENTERTAINMENT/105040329/Campaign-grows-set-early-bump-day-Trump?odyssey=tab|topnews|text|Sports|title=Campaign grows to set early bump day for Trump|author=Dan McFeely|work=Indianapolis Star|date= May 4, 2011|accessdate= May 11, 2011}}</ref> and a Speedway press release stated that Trump cancelled because of his intention to run for President.<ref>{{cite news|author=Weir, Tom|title=Donald Trump bows out of Indy 500 pace car role|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gameon/post/2011/05/donald-trump-bows-out-of-indy-500-pace-car-role/1|date=May 5, 2011|work=USA Today|publisher=Gannett|accessdate=May 7, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
On May 16, Trump announced he would not run for president.
====Statements regarding President Obama====
====Statements regarding President Obama====
Line 199: Line 201:
As the "birther" issue that he championed started fading with the release of President Barack Obama's birth certificate, which occurred on the same weekend as President Obama's historic announcement of the US military's successful capture and killing of international terrorist Osama Bin Laden, so did Trump's popularity. In what the survey shop Public Policy Polling described as "one of the quickest rises and falls in the history of presidential politics," Donald Trump plummeted from a field-leading 26 percent in the polls of potential Republican presidential candidates to a mere 8 percent, which tied him for fifth-place tie with the man he has often criticized as unelectable, Ron Paul.
As the "birther" issue that he championed started fading with the release of President Barack Obama's birth certificate, which occurred on the same weekend as President Obama's historic announcement of the US military's successful capture and killing of international terrorist Osama Bin Laden, so did Trump's popularity. In what the survey shop Public Policy Polling described as "one of the quickest rises and falls in the history of presidential politics," Donald Trump plummeted from a field-leading 26 percent in the polls of potential Republican presidential candidates to a mere 8 percent, which tied him for fifth-place tie with the man he has often criticized as unelectable, Ron Paul.
